introduction.p:
The momentum \vec p of a particle of mass m and velocity \vec u in Newtonian mechanics is given by
\vec p = m\: \vec v.
In Newtonian mechanics this momentum is conserved in every inertial frame. However, when you apply this definition of momentum to a collision process we find that momentum is not conserved in all frames. To get momentum to be conserved we need to modify the definition of mementum to
\vec p = \gamma\: m\: \vec v,
where
\gamma = \frac{1}{\sqrt{ 1- v^2/c^2 }}.
Formula has the same form as formula if we replace original mass by another mass, which we can call relativistic mass,
m_\text{rel} = \frac{m}{\sqrt{ 1- v^2/c^2 }}.
Higher the speed higher the mass gets. At speed of light, relativistic mass becomes infinite if m\ne 0. Original mass m is called rest mass and is often denoted by adding subscript to symbol, m_0. In that case we drop "rel" from m and write this formula as
m = \frac{m_0}{\sqrt{ 1- v^2/c^2 }}.

subsection.title: Derivation of \vec p = \gamma m_0 v
subsection.p: Is there some way we can modify the definition in Eq. so that the law of conservation of momentum is obeyed by the new momentum in every inertial frame and the new definition reduces to the old definition when the speed of the particle is much less than the speed of light?

We will carry out an elementary calculation of a two-dimensinal collision in two frames treating mass as an unknown function of speed. Then, we will guess the function that will ensure momentum is conserved in two frames S and S' that are in relative uniform motion. The setup is shown in where velocities of two particles are shown with respect to frame S'. We assume that the two particles have the same mass when at rest and denote their masses at speed u by symbol m_u.

Conservation of momentum along each axis in the two frames are
S', x:\ \ \amp m_{v'_1}\times 0 + m_{v'_2}(-V) = m_{w'_1}\times 0 + m_{w'_2}(-V) S', y:\ \ \amp m_{v'_1}(-u_0) + m_{v'_2}(v_0/\gamma) = m_{w'_1} w_0 + m_{w'_2}(-s_0/\gamma) S, x:\ \ \amp m_{v_1}(V) + m_{v_2}\times 0 = m_{w_1}(V) + m_{w_2}\times 0 S, y:\ \ \amp m_{v_1}(-u_0/\gamma) + m_{v_2}(v_0) = m_{w_1}(w_0/\gamma) + m_{w_2}(-s_0)
From Eq. we get
m_{v'_2} = m_{w'_2}\ \implies\ v'_2 = w'_2 \ \implies\ v_0 = s_0.
From Eq. we get
m_{v_1} = m_{w_1}\ \implies\ v_1 = w_1 \ \implies\ u_0 = w_0.
Using this in Eq. gives
m_{v'_2} \frac{v_0}{\gamma} = m_{u_0} u_0
Using Eqs. and in Eq you can show
m_{v_2} v_0 = m_{v_1} \frac{u_0}{\gamma}
Now, from these two equations we get
\frac{m_{v'_2}} { \gamma m_{v_2} } = \frac{\gamma m_{u_0}}{m_{v_1}}.
Hence, with v_2 = v_0 this simplifies to
m_{v_1} m_{v'_2} = \gamma^2 m_{u_0} m_{v_0}.
Here
v_1 = \sqrt{V^2 + \frac{u_0^2}{\gamma^2}},\ \ \ v'_2 = \sqrt{V^2 + \frac{v_0^2}{\gamma^2}}.
Now, if we choose v_0 = u_0, then v_1 = v'_2. This simplifies Eq. to
m_{v_1} = \gamma m_{u_0}.
With u_0=0, this equation gives mass when speed is V, m_V, in terms of mass at rest, m_0, which is also called the rest mass.
m_V = \frac{m_0}{\sqrt{ 1- V^2/c^2 }}.
Hence, relativistic momentum of a particle of velocity \vec v is
\vec p = \frac{m_0 \vec v}{\sqrt{ 1- v^2/c^2 }},\ \ \text{or,}\ \ \gamma m_0 \vec v.

subsection.title: What happens to \vec F =d\vec p/dt?
subsection.p:
In Newtonian mechanics, the second law of motion in an inertial frame is
\vec F = \dfrac{d\vec p}{dt},
where \vec p = m \vec v, where \vec v is the instantaneous velocity and m mass. We have already seen that momentum vector in relativity has a different expression. Using the relativistic formula for \vec p, we will get
\vec F \amp = \dfrac{d (\gamma m_0 \vec v)}{dt} \amp \gamma m_0 \vec a + m_0 \vec v \dfrac{d\gamma}{dt}.
Using v^2 = v_x^2 + v_y^2 + v_z^2 in \gamma, we get
\frac{d\gamma}{dt} \amp = -\frac{1}{2}\gamma^3 \left( - \frac{2}{c^2}[v_x a_x + v_y a_y + v_z a_z] \right) \amp = \frac{\gamma^3}{c^2}\: \vec v \cdot \vec a.
Therefore we arrive at
\vec F = \gamma m_0 \vec a + \left( \frac{\gamma^3}{c^2}\: \vec v \cdot \vec a \right)\:m_0 \:\vec v.
In one dimension, say x-direction, with v_y=v_z=0, this simplifies to
F_x = \gamma^3\:m_0\:a_x,
since
\amp \gamma m_0 a_x + \left( \frac{\gamma^3}{c^2}\: v_xa_x\right)\:m_0 \:v_x = \gamma m_0 a_x \left( 1 + \gamma^2 \frac{v_x^2}{c^2} \right) \amp \ \ \ \ \ = \gamma m_0 a_x \left( 1 + \frac{v_x^2/c^2}{\sqrt{1 - v_x^2/c^2}} \right) = \gamma^2 m_0 a_x.
We rarely use these formulas in practice. But, its good to know that there is a way of think of force in relativistic terms.

exercise.title: Relativistic Equation of Motion of an Electron in a Constant Electric Field

statement.p: In a linear accelerator an electron is accelerated by a constant electric field \vec E in the opposite direction to its velocity \vec u. Find the equation of motion of the electron.

solution.p:
Let the velocity of the electron be towards the positive x-axis. Then, electric field is towards the negative x-axis and force on the electron is towards the positive x-axis. Eq. takes the following form.
eE = \dfrac{d}{dt}\left[\dfrac{m_0 u_x}{\sqrt{1- u_x^2/c^2}} \right],\ \ u_y = 0, \ \ u_z = 0.
Expanding the derivative on the right side we obtain
eE = m_0 \gamma^3\: \dfrac{du_x}{dt},\ \ u_y = 0, \ \ u_z = 0.

exercise.title: Equation of Motion of an Electron in a Cyclotron

statement.p: In a cyclotron an electron is accelerated by a constant magnetic field \vec B perpendicular to the velocity \vec u of the electron. The electron moves in a circle of radius R with a constant speed. Find the equation of motion of the electron.

solution.p:
Suppose the circle of motion is in the xy-plane and the magnetic field is towards the positive z-axis. The velocity of the electron will be in the \hat u_\theta direction so that the force is radially in towards the center of the circle. Let us write the velocity of the electron as \vec u = u \hat u_\theta. Eq. takes the following form.
e u B (-\hat u_r) = \dfrac{d}{dt}\left[\dfrac{m_0 u \hat u_\theta}{\sqrt{1- u^2/c^2}} \right],\ \ u_r = 0, \ \ u_z = 0.
Expanding the derivative on the right side we obtain
e u B (-\hat u_r)= \dfrac{m_0 u}{\sqrt{1- u^2/c^2}} \: \dfrac{d\hat u_\theta}{dt},\ \ u_r = 0, \ \ u_z = 0.
The derivative of \hat u_\theta will give a product of d\theta/dt and -\hat u_r. Therefore, magnitude on the two sides will equal giving
e B = \dfrac{m_0 }{\sqrt{1- u^2/c^2}} \: \dfrac{d \theta}{dt},\ \ u_r = 0, \ \ u_z = 0.
Since the speed in the circle is uniform, we have u = R\: d\theta/dt giving us the following equation.
e B R = p,
which has the same form as the equation p = e B R in the non-relativistic case, except now, p is the relativistic momentum.

exercise.title: Relativisitc Momentum Versus Ordinary Momentum of an Electron

statement.p: An electron is moving at a speed of 0.9\: c, i.e. at 90\% of the speed of light. Compare its momentum calculated from the relativistic formula to the one calculated from the Newtonian formula.

answer.p: Relativisitic momentum to be 2.29 times the Newtonian value.

solution.p:
The mass of an electron is m_0 = 9.11\times 10^{-31}\;\textrm{kg}. Let us first calculate \gamma for the speed.
\gamma = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-u^2/c^2}} = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-0.9^2}} = 2.29.
The momentum of the electron from Newtonian expression is
p_{\textrm{Newton}} \amp = m_0 u = 9.11\times 10^{-31}\;\textrm{kg} \times 0.9\times 3\times 10^{8}\:\textrm{m/s} \amp = 2.46\times 10^{-22}\:\textrm{kg.m/s}.
The momentum of the same electron from relativistic expression is
p_{\textrm{Einstein}} \amp = \gamma m_0 u = 2.29\times 2.46\times 10^{-22}\:\textrm{kg.m/s} \amp = 5.63\times 10^{-22}\:\textrm{kg.m/s}.
The correct momentum is given by the relativistic formula, which gives momentum to be 2.29 times the Newtonian value.

exercise.title: Relativisitic Momentum of a Proton in Lab Frame

statement.p: A proton is moving with speed 0.95 c with respect to lab. (a) What is its momentum in the lab frame? (b) What is its momentum in its rest frame? Data: m_p = 1.67 \times 10{-27}\text{ kg}.

solution.p:
(a) In the lab frame proton is moving at reltivistic speed. Therefore, we will use relativisitic formula. We will compute \gamma first.
\gamma = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1- (v/c)^2}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1- 0.9^2}} = 3.20.
Therefore, momentum will be
p \amp = \gamma m_0 v = 1.29 \times ( 1.67 \times 10{-27}\text{ kg} \times 0.95 \times 3\times 10^{8}\text{ m/s} ) \amp = 3.20 \times 4.76 \times 10^{-19}\text{ kg.m/s} = 1.52 \times 10^{-18}\text{ kg.m/s}
(b) This is already calculated in (a). Its the part when \gamma=1. Ans: 4.76 \times 10^{-19}\text{ kg.m/s}.

exercise.title: Error When Using Non-Relativisitc Formula for Momentum

statement.p: A proton is moving with speed 0.95 c with respect to lab. Find the percentage error you will make in calculating the momentum in the lab frame if you treat this proton by Newtonian mechanics.

solution.p:
Using the results in , we get
\fracr{1.52 \times 10^{-18}\text{ kg.m/s} - 4.76 \times 10^{-19}\text{ kg.m/s}}{4.76 \times 10^{-19}\text{ kg.m/s}} = 2.19 = 219\%.

exercise.title: Momentum of a Proton with respect to an Antiproton

statement.p: A proton and an antiproton (same mass as proton) in a high-energy accelerator are moving towards each other. Both have speed of 0.90 c with respect to lab. What is the momentum of proton with respect to the antiproton? Data: m_p = 1.67 \times 10{-27}\text{ kg}.

hint.p: Use velocity addition formula to obtain the speed of proton with respect to the antiproton.

solution.p:
We need to find the speed of proton with respect to the antiproton. By using velocity addition rule, we get
v = \frac{0.9 c + 0.9 c}{ 1 + 0.9^2 } = 0.9945 c.
Therefore,
\gamma = \frac{1}{\sqrt{ 1 - 0.9945^2 }} = 90.75.
Therefore, required momentum will be
p = \gamma m_0 v = = 90.75 \times 1.67 \times 10{-27}\text{ kg} \times 0.9945 c = 4.52\times 10^{-17}\text{ kg.m/s}.
